title: Dennis Morton Horne
text:
Dennis Morton Horne (19 October 1920 – 3 May 2015) was an <a href="England">English</a> <a href="chess">chess</a> player. <a href="Chess%20Olympiad">Chess Olympiad</a> individual silver medal winner (<a href="10th%20Chess%20Olympiad">1952</a>).
Biography.
After <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, Dennis Morton Horne retired from the army as a captain and studied at <a href="University%20of%20Oxford">University of Oxford</a>, where he became seriously obsessed with chess. In the 1948 <a href="Plymouth">Plymouth</a> International Chess Tournament, he won the former World chess champion <a href="Max%20Euwe">Max Euwe</a>. In 1949 he won the 2nd place in <a href="Swiss-system%20tournament">Swiss-system</a> <a href="British%20Chess%20Championship">British Chess Championship</a>. He was a sharp-style chess player, often using such chess opening as <a href="King%27s%20Gambit">King's Gambit</a>. Dennis Morton Horne represented the English team in <a href="Chess%20Olympiad">Chess Olympiad</a> in <a href="10th%20Chess%20Olympiad">1952</a>, where he won an individual silver medal. In 1954, he still took part in the <a href="Hastings%20International%20Chess%20Congress">Hastings International Chess Congress</a>, which, although surpassing <a href="Fri%C3%B0rik%20%C3%93lafsson">Friðrik Ólafsson</a>, still ranks last. In later years, the less time Dennis Morton Hornespent on chess, the more he became obsessed with <a href="Contract%20bridge">Contract bridge</a>.
